webTitle: Game Group to enter administration

fields.standfirst: Fears for 6,000 UK jobs as troubled retailer's shares are suspended and it admits its business is worthless
fields.body:
The future of Game Group is hanging by a thread after it filed for administration and admitted the business was worthless, jeopardising 6,000 jobs in the UK.

The video game retailer has been trying to negotiate a rescue deal with the private equity firm OpCapita which recently bought electrical goods retailer Comet, but its offer has been blocked by Game's lenders, led by the Royal Bank of Scotland.

Game shops remain open and a fire sale has started. The company admitted on Wednesday that the business had "no equity value" when its shares were suspended from stock exchange trading.

The company, which runs 1,270 shops, half of them in the UK, and employs 10,000 people worldwide, needs to raise around £180m to stave off collapse. Sales have been hit after several suppliers refused to deliver new game titles, including Mass Effect 3, Mario Party 9 and Street Fighter X Tekken. Game has been trying to raise cash through a "spring clean" sale on its website, with games priced at £1.98.

"There are definitely some good bargains to be had," said Piers Harding-Rolls, head of games at research firm IHS Screen Digest.

The group's notice of intention to appoint administrators, thought to be PricewaterhouseCoopers, has given it a fortnight's breathing space which will protect the company from creditors.

It is a desperate race against time, as Game faces a £21m quarterly rent bill on Sunday and a £12m wage bill at the end of the month. It also owes more than £10m in VAT, £40m to suppliers, and up to £100m to seven lenders – RBS, Barclays, HSBC, HSBC Australia, La Caixa, Allied Irish Banks and Bank of Ireland.

OpCapita and the banks have been trading recriminations after a proposal put forward by OpCapita last week was rejected.

An OpCapita spokesman said: "We put forward a fully funded proposal which would have preserved Game as a viable business in partnership with the suppliers, who have been very supportive."

However, sources close to the lenders claimed that OpCapita did not come up with a fully funded unconditional proposal, and were unable to provide Game's directors with an assurance this would be a solvent solution for the company.

The US retailer GameStop and turnaround specialist Hilco have also been rumoured to be in the frame.

While a deal with OpCapita looks unlikely at present, the idea of a rescue involving just the banks and suppliers has been floated. But sources close to OpCapita warned suppliers that they would probably be wiped out. Either way, job losses are likely as Game could only survive as a much slimmed-down company.

Game has been burning through cash after suffering dire trading in recent months, which forced the chain to ask its suppliers for more generous terms. It came close to breaching its borrowing covenants and lost its credit insurance, at which point it gave preferential treatment to some suppliers – infuriating the others.

Game's problems went from bad to worse when three leading game publishers withdrew their latest hits from sale at the retailer. Mass Effect 3 publisher Electronic Arts, Mario Party publisher Nintendo and Capcom, the company behind Street Fighter X Tekken and the Resident Evil games, refused to provide new titles, fearing that they would not be able to reclaim the stock if Game went bust.

Game had signalled that losses for the year to the end of January were likely to be around £18m, but on Wednesday the board admitted that it was "unable to assess the business's financial position".

The games market has seen a big shift to digital downloads. Gamers have also been buying more on the internet, but several upcoming console launches should benefit Game if it manages to secure a rescue deal. The new Wii U is expected to be launched later this year, while an updated Microsoft Xbox 360 could be out next year.

Game has stores, some trading under the brand Gamestation, in France, Spain, eastern Europe and Australia.

webTitle: Aviva chief enjoys pay boost despite profits slump

fields.standfirst: Andrew Moss sees salary jump nearly 4% to £980,000, while head of Intercontinental Hotels receives £1.1m amid profits leap
fields.body:
Several companies slipped out their annual reports on budget day, with the insurer Aviva announcing that Andrew Moss, its chief executive, collected a pay and perks package worth up to £5m last year, even though company profits fell.

Richard Solomons, head of Intercontinental Hotels, was paid a total of £1.1m, up from £996,000 in 2010 after the company disclosed a 26% increase in profits.

Aviva, the UK's second-biggest insurer, recently announced a pre–tax profits slump to £87m last year, compared with £2.4bn in 2010, due to "adverse unrealised investment variances". These included a £726m charge relating to its holding in Delta Lloyd, the Dutch insurer it once owned.

Moss saw his basic salary jump nearly 4% to £980,000; he is also in line for £2.5m under a longer-term incentive plan, or 275% of his salary, if certain targets are met. Other perks come to about £1.6m. Moss continues to receive 2% of basic salary as a non-pensionable cash supplement provided in consideration of his surrendering an unapproved retirement scheme. He also gets a £19,000 "cash car allowance".

Aviva said the company met key financial targets last year, with the operating performance improving. Moss will receive share bonuses only if "stretching targets" are met.

webTitle: Sainsbury's breezy trading figures keep doomsayers at bay

fields.bodyText: Spotting the moment when Sainsbury's slips up has been a popular guessing-game among retail-watchers. The wait goes on. Wednesday's trading numbers were breezier than forecast – like-for-like sales, excluding fuel, were up 2.6% in the past three months. The share price, which has recently spent time below 300p on the thought that a wounded Tesco would take a swing at Sainsbury's, rose 4.5% to 319p. As it happens, Tesco may not present the greatest medium-term headache. Justin King, Sainsbury's chief executive, took a risk when he adopted a price-match policy on branded goods but the strategy seems to have blunted the market leader's biggest weapon. The real fight is instead being conducted in "softer" areas, such as marketing and service, in which Sainsbury's currently looks better equipped. No, the greater financial threat is probably the one that faces the entire supermarket sector: too many shops and too much new space under construction. There's a classic dilemma here – over-capacity will hurt everybody but, since new stores are still the quickest way to reach new customers (yes, even in the age of home deliveries), nobody wants to be the first to stop building. It's really a question of relative pain. Who is most at risk of cannibalising their own sales via expansion? On that score, Sainsbury's looks better placed than most since it is under-represented in the north and Scotland, where its opening programme is concentrated. To repeat, it's only a relative advantage – but it's worth something.

webTitle: ENRC promises boardroom change as profits fall

fields.standfirst: The company, which was shaken by a boardroom bust-up last year, is keen to bolster its corporate governance credentials to curry favour with international investors
fields.body:
ENRC, the London-listed Kazakh mining firm, is promising to bring in new directors to "refresh" its management team as it seeks to regain its poise after reporting a fall in profit in 2011.

The company, which was shaken by a boardroom bust-up last year, is keen to bolster its corporate governance credentials to curry favour with international investors. Analysts have suggested its share price could be higher if it was run on more conventional lines.

Chairman Mehmet Dalman admitted in an interview with the Guardian the board had been "dysfunctional" in the past, but said that was no longer the case after reforms last year.

Ken Olisa, a former British non-executive who was ousted after last year's tumultuous annual meeting, famously described the company as "more Soviet than City". Floated in 2007, it has been rocked by disagreements over strategy.

Three Kazakh oligarchs own more than 35% of the company; a further 12% is owned by the Republic of Kazakhstan. Kazakhmys, another miner, owns 26%.

Today, ENRC blamed rising costs for its weak financial performance, citing wage and energy inflation and a bigger bill linked to the price of raw materials used by its manufacturing operations.

A big producer of ferrochrome, an essential component of stainless steel, ENRC is one of Kazakhstan's largest companies, accounting for 3% of the country's GDP in 2009. ENRC employs more than 70,000 people, of which 65,000 are located in Kazakhstan.

Profits dived 7.5% to $2.7bn (£1.7bn) last year as costs rose 24% to $3.5bn in a year that saw record capital expenditure of nearly $2bn. The company is planning to cut costs by $150m this year, partly by reducing headcount in Kazakhstan. Some activities could be outsourced to generate further efficiencies.

Rival Kazakhmys this month reported real inflation in Kazakhstan at almost three times the official rate.

Dalman, a former City investment banker at Commerzbank and Deutsche Bank, who took over from Johannes Sittard in February, said: "We have continued to review board composition, mindful of the need to progressively refresh the board, with a view to affording it with talented and dedicated directors. I will lead this effort and I will be in a position to report back to you on our progress in the not too distant future."

ENRC needs to recruit a new senior independent director to replace Dalman, who held that role before becoming chairman. One other non-executive is being sought. Dalman said he expected to announce appointments in "weeks rather than months". He said ENRC's share price did not reflect the company's intrinsic worth and should be substantially higher than today's (Wed) 646p. Dalman said it was his understanding that non-executive director Sir Paul Judge intended to stay with the company even though it was reported last year that he wanted the chairmanship.

Felix Vulis, ENRC chief executive, was optimistic about future prospects. He said: "Although the volatility in global markets persists in 2012, particularly concerning the sovereign debt crisis in Europe, we remain confident in the outlook for our diversified mix of commodities due to sustained growth in emerging markets."

In January, ENRC agreed to pay $1.25bn to settle a long-running dispute with Canada's First Quantum Minerals over assets in the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

ENRC sparked uproar when it bought the Kolwezi copper mining project in the war-ravaged African country. The operation had belonged to First Quantum but it had been seized by the DRC government, which accused the Canadians of contract violations. City analysts said ENRC's action had alienated shareholders and several big investors, including Standard Life, sold their holdings in protest.

The agreement was struck on the basis that First Quantum drops all legal claims against the DRC and ENRC; the DRC has also pledged to terminate its claims against First Quantum.

webTitle: Budget 2012: chancellor earmarks £60m for aerospace research centre

fields.standfirst: Government hopes UK Centre for Aerodynamics will capitalise on huge demand for aircraft and reinvigorate aerospace industry
fields.body:
A research institution built across several sites in Britain will develop and test "radical" designs of wings and other components for the aerospace industry with £60m from the budget.

The government hopes the UK Centre for Aerodynamics, scheduled to open next year, will capitalise on the huge demand for new aircraft and reinvigorate an industry that has seen investment falter in recent years.

The chancellor earmarked aviation as part of Britain's "industrial ambition" to turn the country into "Europe's technology centre".

Over the next 20 years, the aviation market will require around 27,000 new large aircraft worth nearly £2tn. The market for unmanned drones also has potential for dramatic growth.

A further £100m was pledged to universities to build research facilities in partnership with industry and charities, which the government hopes will add more than £200m to the projects. The top-up follows a savage 50% cut to research capital funds in 2010.

"I suspect the government realises that the multi-billion pound, 50% cut made to research capital in 2010 simply is not sustainable," said Imran Khan, director of the Campaign for Science and Engineering. "Despite difficult times, they are trying to put it right, and it is not going unnoticed."

Sir Paul Nurse, president of the Royal Society, said the funds for universities and the new aerospace centre were welcome but no more than "green shoots".

"In the UK, the government and industry still invest a smaller percentage of our GDP in research and development than our competitor economies," he said. "And while that remains the case, we will not fulfil the chancellor's goal of making the UK into Europe's technology centre.

"If we want science to improve our situation, we must think bigger than our competitors in investing in the full range of science and innovation from discovery, through development and on to application."

webTitle: APR Energy's delayed results fiasco leaves it running low on power

fields.bodyText: About this week's results announcement: there won't be one. We're terribly sorry, but we haven't got the audited numbers ready. We ran out of time. A lot has happened in the last year – a couple of big transactions and our arrival on the London Stock Exchange – and it's all very complicated. Don't worry, though, we can tell you now that the numbers will be fine on, ahem, 16 April. That was gist on APR Energy's after-hours announcement on Tuesday and the share price reacted in understandable fashion the next day – falling 20%. Delaying your results announcement because you haven't got the numbers ready is virtually unheard-of. APR will not live this down quickly. It's a shame because APR had a lot going for it as an alternative to Aggreko, a FTSE 100 company, in the market for supplying temporary power facilities. The growth story still seems to be intact (assuming the numbers are indeed okay when they finally arrive) but there's a sizeable constituency of investors that will take the view that a company is off-limits if it can't hit a basic deadline. It's not an unreasonable view since there are a couple of thousand other companies on the London market that do hit their deadlines. APR's road back to credibility, and an Aggreko-style high rating, is likely to be long.

webTitle: Jaguar Land Rover and China's Chery agree joint venture

fields.standfirst: Tie-up, if approved by regulators, will give JLR a burgeoning production base in one of its fastest-growing markets
fields.body:
Jaguar Land Rover has clinched a joint venture deal with China's Chery Automobile in a move that promises to boost sales in one of its fastest-growing markets.

Sales of JLR's sleek saloons and powerful SUVs in China have boomed in recent years as luxury cars remain in demand, even as the overall market cools.

China is JLR's third largest market after the UK and US. One in six Land Rovers, Range Rovers and Jaguars built last year were shipped to China, where sales grew to 42,000, an increase of more than 60% in a year.

In 2000, China produced more than 2m cars. In 2011, that figure had risen to about 18.5m.

Chery and JLR are understood to be seeking regulatory approval for the $2.8bn (£1.8bn) venture to manufacture and sell luxury cars in China, although that could be only weeks away.

Wednesday's agreement is a boost for JLR, which is owned by India's Tata Motors and is Britain's biggest employer within the industry with a workforce of more than 21,000. Sales in China contributed 17.2% of JLR's revenue in the quarter to the end of December, more than the UK, the birthplace of the two brands.

A push into emerging markets such as China and Russia has been one of the key factors in the turnaround in JLR's fortunes since Tata bought the brands in 2008.

The China tie-up, if approved, would give JLR a much sought-after production base in a market where global luxury carmakers, including BMW and Daimler AG's Mercedes-Benz, are reaping benefits from the growing ranks of wealthy Chinese.

JLR and Chery will look to share research and development, technology and manufacturing knowledge across the joint venture, the companies said. They added: "Demand for Jaguar and Land Rover vehicles continues to increase significantly in China, and we believe that JLR and Chery can jointly realise the potential of these iconic brands."

The venture, to be located near Shanghai in Changshu city, will initially make Land Rover SUVs, followed by Jaguars in the second phase. "This is an important step for JLR and Tata Motors," Vineet Hetamasaria, auto analyst at PINC Research in Mumbai, told Reuters. "This is only an agreement, and it will be some time before we see the results."

A new, jointly owned company will be formed, with a view to establishing a research and development facility. It will aim to develop and manufacture new models, as well as set up engine manufacturing operations and create a sales network in China. Both firms said they wished to "leverage" their respective strengths.

Recently, JLR said it was creating 1,000 jobs in the West Midlands as the firm continued to roar back to financial health. That announcement confirmed a remarkable recovery by the carmaker, which was close to seeking a state bailout during the credit crunch.

JLR said the jobs in Solihull would be dedicated to increasing production of the Range Rover, Range Rover Sport, Discovery and Defender.

webTitle: Time running out for Lloyds in branch sale

fields.bodyText: Lloyds Banking Group has just seven more working days if it is to meet its promise to update the City by the end of the first quarter of 2012 on talks about selling 632 of its branches to Co-operative Bank. In December, when the bank selected the Co-op as the preferred bidder for the branches, it said its aim was to "agree heads of terms by the end of Q1 2012". The branches must be sold under state aid rules set out by the EU and Lloyds has made clear that it is continuing to "progress" a potential stock market flotation in case the deal falls through. A continuation of the informal deadline for talks with the Co-op is likely to be needed to allow all the complex issues to be ironed out. While the market awaits details of the sale, Lloyds raised £170m from shareholders today through an issue of new shares intended to raise cash to pay holders of certain types of its bonds. It is not exactly a large sum for a bank that received a £20bn bailout, but it does provide a small psychological boost for the management: on issuing the new shares, the bank has managed to dilute the Treasury's stake to below 40% to 39.75% – one way at least to reduce the taxpayer's stake in the bailed-out bank. Although at this rate, it would take 80 years to extricate the taxpayer completely.

webTitle: Threat of recession receding but economy still at risk, says OBR

fields.standfirst: Office for Budget Responsibility's economic outlook raises growth forecast slightly but predicts slow recovery
fields.body:
Britain's chances of slipping into recession have receded but the economy still faces threats from sluggish consumer spending, the eurozone crisis and high oil prices, the Office for Budget Responsibility has warned.

Publishing their economic outlook alongside George Osborne's budget, the independent forecasters said growth would be slightly stronger than first feared this year but it painted a picture of a slow road to recovery and slashed forecasts for business investment.

"The economy carried a little more momentum into the new year than previously anticipated," the OBR chairman, Robert Chote, said, raising the 2012 growth forecast to 0.8% from 0.7% pencilled in last November.

"The underlying picture is one in which growth is pretty stable through to the autumn and then picks up towards the end of the year," he added, but warned potential output would not be back to its long-term average growth rate until 2014.

Despite the new year uptick in activity, the OBR would not go so far as to rule out a technical recession, defined by two consecutive quarters of contraction. The UK economy shrank in the final months of 2011.

It put the chances that the UK economy would shrink this year versus 2011 at "roughly" one-in-four.

It said the "key risks" stemmed from the sovereign debt crisis in the eurozone and from a further spike in oil prices, which have already hit $127 a barrel this year.

Within the UK, the forecasters warned consumer spending would continue to act as a drag on overall growth and that pressure would not lift until income growth significantly outstrips the pace of inflation in 2014.

One of the biggest uncertainties in its growth outlook came from business investment, which the government has been banking on as a key driver in the recovery.

After a dismal outturn at the end of last year, business investment growth was slashed to just 0.7% this year from 7.7% predicted back in November. "We believe that non-financial companies' balance sheets may be weaker than official statistics suggest," the OBR said.

The outlook was still too punchy for forecasters at the respected thinktank the National Institute of Economic and Social Research (NIESR).

"Continued uncertainty, combined with funding problems in the banking sector, are likely to result in a sharp fall in business investment and a negative contribution from inventory accumulation this year, keeping the economy broadly flat," it said.

The outlook for unemployment remained bleak with the OBR forecasting the jobless rate would peak at 8.7% this year and edge down only slightly next year to 8.6%.

The OBR's latest forecasts for the economy, which it sees growing 2% next year, are slightly more optimistic than those of other forecasters but a little more pessimistic than the latest outlook from the Bank of England.

Economists said it was unsurprising the OBR had held off making any big upward revisions to the outlook despite a pick-up in the tone of economic indicators and business surveys in recent weeks.

Philip Shaw at Investec commented: "Has the economic environment not improved since last autumn? At first glance the absence of an upgrade to the macro forecasts might seem inconsistent with the better tone to financial markets so far this year. Arguably though what has changed is that the downside risks facing the world economy have faded, without an appreciable change in the main case outlook."

webTitle: Kraft spins off snacks business into new Mondelez International company

fields.standfirst: US food giant hopes new name chosen after suggestion by employees will be to the taste of shareholders
fields.body:
What do you get if you combine Cadbury's chocolate, Trident gum and Dairylea? A "delicious world", according to the US food giant Kraft.

The company is spinning off its global snacks business and seeking shareholder approval to call the new entity Mondelez International.

The company said the name (pronounced mohn-dah-leez) was inspired by suggestions from two Kraft employees after a global competition. The name combines "monde", the French for world, and "delez", which is supposed to suggest "delicious". None of the brands under Mondelez's control will change their names. The US business will also remain as Kraft, and there will be no Mondelez Creme Eggs or Mondelez Philadelphia Cream Cheese.

The two firms will be listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

"The Kraft brand is a perfect fit for the North American grocery business and gives it a wonderful platform on which to build an exciting future," the chairman and chief executive, Irene Rosenfeld, said.

"For the new global snacks company, we wanted to find a new name that could serve as an umbrella for our iconic brands, reinforce the truly global nature of this business and build on our higher purpose – to 'make today delicious'. "

The company announced last year that it was splitting its business.

Kraft, the world's second-largest food manufacturer, bought Cadbury in January 2010, and the split is intended to create a snacks business with the flexibility to make additional acquisitions.

It remains to be seen how delicious Kraft's shareholders will find Mondelez. They will get the chance to vote on the name at the company's annual general meeting in May.

webTitle: Budget 2012: young entrepreneurs to get student-style loans

fields.standfirst: Sir Richard Branson says pilot youth enterprise scheme will help prevent a lost generation of talent
fields.body:
The government will lend young entrepreneurs money to start their own business on similar terms to student loans, under a pilot scheme to be launched later this year.

Sir Richard Branson, who has been lobbying alongside young businesspeople for a £10m youth enterprise loan scheme, welcomed the announcement in Wednesday's budget.

"The entrepreneurs of today will be the job creators of tomorrow so I'm delighted that the government has listened to those at the very start of their careers," said the Virgin founder. "The country is full of gifted and enterprising people so this pilot, which crucially has business mentoring and support at its heart, will help prevent a lost generation of talent."

An online information-sharing community for 2,000 startups, organised by Virgin Media, has been arguing that loans should be available for young businesspeople on the same terms as those for university studies.

Students are able to borrow at an interest rate based on RPI inflation and have to make repayments only when their earnings exceed £21,000 a year.

Other measures to tackle youth unemployment announced on Wednesday included £20m of new money to support 19,000 degree-level apprenticeships, topping up £180m committed last year.

"Young people get a loan to go to university or college," said the chancellor, George Osborne. "Now we want to help them get a loan to start their own business."

Abdul Khan, founder of ratethatcurry.com and a member of the Virgin Media Pioneer startup community, described the scheme as "just the sort of financial help young entrepreneurs need in this tough economic climate".

The business and enterprise minister Mark Prisk said: "This government thinks that everyone should have a chance to turn their idea for a business into reality. That's why in the budget this year we announced we are setting up a youth enterprise loan scheme."

webTitle: Budget 2012: George Osborne sets UK firms £1 trillion export target

fields.standfirst: Manufacturers say budget lacks detailed economic vision for UK and call for more government help to meet 2020 goal
fields.body:
George Osborne pressed the accelerator on the "march of the makers" on Wednesday by challenging companies to double exports to £1tn by the end of the decade, prompting calls from manufacturers for more assistance in order to meet his goal.

A day after the chancellor announced a £20bn credit easing scheme for small- and medium-sized companies, he unveiled a wave of measures to support his ambitious target, including a change to tax credits for research and development.

Osborne emulated the tactics of peers in France and Germany by singling out specific industries for help as he announced a £60m investment in a UK centre for aerodynamics. Previously, the government has ruled out an industrial strategy of picking winners, but it is now indicating it is willing to focus on certain sectors.

However, the manufacturers' organisation, the EEF, said the budget lacked a detailed economic vision for the UK and was undermined by weak investment data from the government's independent forecaster, the Office for Budget Responsibility, which says business investment growth will be 0.7% this year, compared with earlier predictions of growth of more than 7%. Lee Hopley, chief economist at the EEF, said doubling annual exports to £1tn by 2020 required a sustainable growth strategy that, according to the OBR, would not yield results this year. Manufactured goods account for about half of all UK exports.

"If rebalancing the economy is about having more sustainable growth, more business investment and a net trade position, then there is now a question mark as to whether that process will get under way this year," said Hopley.

She said tapping developing markets would be key to reaching the £1tn target: "I don't think it will be an easy target to hit because companies have to be making those investments over the next couple of years if they want to win share in some of those markets."

The EEF said more government help was needed for supply chain companies, which comprise a significant part of the UK's small and medium-sized business community and typically make products for major manufacturers.

John Cridland, director general of the Confederation of British Industry, said Osborne's announcement of investments in aerodynamics and pharmaceuticals was a positive sign for manufacturers.

"I don't think he will be picking [company] winners but he will be picking winning sectors and that's absolutely the right thing to do," he said. "British businesses had lost the global trading habit in recent years, so the £1tn target is aspirational but it is what we should be doing."

The government confirmed that it would extend research and development tax credits to loss-making companies as well as profitable businesses, a lobbying coup for manufacturers who account for more than two-thirds of R&D investment in the UK.

webTitle: Budget 2012: budget deficit still looms large for George Osborne

fields.standfirst: Under the Office for Budget Responsibility's latest forecasts, the national debt is now expected to continue rising, from 67.3% of GDP this year, to peak at 76.3% of GDP in 2014-15
fields.body:
George Osborne scotched rumours in the run-up to Wednesday's's budget that he would splash out the £5-10bn City experts believed he would have to spare in the current financial year, promising instead to use any wriggle room to reduce the government's debts.

This morning it became clear why: tax revenues in February were so weak that there was no windfall left. Figures published by the Office for National Statistics just hours before the budget revealed a much larger than expected deficit of more than £15bn last month alone.

As Osborne put the finishing touches to his statement, it underlined the tough challenge he faces in meeting his deficit-cutting targets over the next five years.

The independent Office for Budget Responsibility, which published its forecasts for the Treasury's finances alongside the budget, now expects a deficit for 2011-12 as a whole of £126bn, or 8.3% of GDP, almost unchanged from the £127bn it was projecting at the autumn statement in November. That will fall to £92bn in the next financial year, the OBR believes, and £21bn, or 1.1% of GDP by 2016-17 as the spending squeeze takes hold in earnest.

Wednesday's statement included a batch of high-profile announcements, including a cut in the 50p top tax rate, a faster than expected reduction in corporation tax, and a £1,100 increase in the personal allowance - a package which Osborne promised to help Britain "earn its way in the world".

But the OBR said the overall impact of these measures would be "broadly neutral" over its five year forecasting period, with each giveaway matched by a tax grab somewhere else. Meanwhile Osborne is sticking rigidly to his programme of spending cuts, as much as 80% of which are still to come, according to a recent analysis by the Institute for Fiscal Studies.

"All in all, this was the Budget of small numbers that we had expected to see," said Chris Crowe, UK economist at Barclays Capital.

Under the OBR's latest forecasts, the national debt is now expected to continue rising, from 67.3% of GDP this year, to peak at 76.3% of GDP in 2014-15, marginally lower than the 78% the OBR had previously expected.

It will be falling by 2015-16, in accordance with Osborne's fiscal target, the OBR predicted. It added that the chancellor also had a "more than 50%" chance of meeting his other key budget target, of eliminating the "structural deficit" - the shortfall in the public finances once the state of the economy is accounted for - over a five year period.

The picture is complicated in the short-term by the transfer of Royal Mail's pension fund to the Exchequer, confirmed by Osborne, which the coalition hopes will make the state-owned postal operator a more attractive proposition for a private sector buyer.

Public accounting rules mean the scheme's assets are brought onto the books immediately, boosting the finances by £28bn. But it also has longer-term liabilities of £37.5bn, which will eventually more than wipe out those assets as pensions are paid out.

Another short-term boost to the exchequer will come from the faster than expected drawdown of troops from Afghanistan, which will save Osborne £800m next year, and £1.5bn in 2014-15.

In line with analysis from HM Revenue, published with the Budget, the OBR said it had slashed its estimate of the yield from the 50p tax rate to £100m because of widespread avoidance (though it insisted there was "huge uncertainty" around these numbers). The projected income from tax on North Sea oil was also revised down, because of lower than expected production.

However, the government has little room for manoeuvre in meeting its targets for reducing the deficit, and the ratings agency Fitch warned last week that the UK could be stripped of its AAA-rating if a loss of nerve by the chancellor, or a weaker than expected recovery, knocks the public finances off course.

"With little policy flexibility in hand, the short-term path of activity is largely out of the hands of the authorities. The deficit may take longer to fall than is forecast, meaning that the peak in the government debt ratio would be higher and it may take longer for debt to be put on a declining path," said Crowe. "In these circumstances, a loss of the triple-A credit rating would seem quite likely."

webTitle: Retailers rise after Sainsbury results and Sunday trading plans, but Weir drops on rival's warning

fields.standfirst: Shop owners, north sea companies and housebuilders all boosted by budget measures
fields.body:
Although the impact of the budget on the overall market was rather muted, retailers benefited from confirmation that Sunday trading laws would be relaxed during the Olympics.

J Sainsbury was the biggest riser of the day in the leading index. Its shares closed 13.8p higher at 319.3p, also helped by upbeat trading news. Marks & Spencer, up 9.5p at 389.5p, benefited from a positive update from Spain's Inditex, owner of the Zara chain.

Debenhams added 1.75p to 78.3p as Societe Generale raised its target price from 69p to 78p in the wake of Tuesday's trading update. Dixons Retail rose 1.33p to 18.8p and Home Retail was 6.6p higher at 122.5p.

But Ted Baker lost 12.5p to 775p as it reported flat profits of £24m after exceptional items. Freddie George at Seymour Pierce said:

In our view, the exceptional costs of £2.8m were not properly flagged to the market. They related to rent for stores on stores not yet opened, set up costs in relation to China and provision for bad and doubtful debts in Greece. Ted Baker is a relatively safe investment, has a strong balance sheet and as with SuperGroup has a great opportunity to develop its brands on the internet and overseas. webTitle: Sainsbury's expects summer of celebration to boost sales

fields.standfirst: Sainsbury's chief executive Justin King says Olympics and jubilee celebrations will help supermarket food sales
fields.body:
Sainsbury's hopes a summer of events, including the London Olympics and the Queen's diamond jubilee, will boost sales by tempting consumers to splash out on fancy food for parties and picnics.

Justin King, chief executive of the UK's third-biggest supermarket, said the Olympics, Paralympics and the jubilee would be "wonderful opportunities for us and our customers to celebrate. We expect these to underpin our performance."

King's comments came as J Sainsbury reported a better-than-expected jump in sales that helped it narrow the gap with market leader Tesco and second-placed Asda. The company said the continued success of its Taste the Difference food range helped lift like-for-like sales, excluding fuel, by 2.6% in the 10 weeks to 17 March.

Sainsbury's increased its share of UK grocery spending to 16.6% in the three months to 19 February, while Tesco's share dropped to 29.7%, the lowest for almost seven years, according to the latest data from Kantar Worldpanel. Tesco, which overtook Sainsbury's to take the top spot in 1995, issued a shock profits warning in January, which wiped £5bn off the value of the company. Last week Tesco's UK head, Richard Brasher, quit.

Retail analyst Nick Bubb said: "Sainsbury's is still hitting the right notes with its marketing and advertising and are entitled to be confident of standing up to whatever Tesco will throw at them."

Caroline Gulliver, analyst at Espírito Santo, said she expected Sainsbury's to "keep its sales momentum over at least the next couple of quarters".

Although King was optimistic about the year ahead, he warned that the stalling economy would continue to make life difficult for consumers for months to come. "The economic climate is likely to remain challenging, and we are committed to helping customers make their money go as far as possible," he said.

He said the 10% sales growth in Sainsbury's "basics" range and the 20% sales growth in its fancier "Taste the Difference" range reflected consumers "saving money so that they can still enjoy special food and special occasions, rather than any loosening of household budgets".

King said Sainsbury's had added 1.4m sq ft of shopping aisles over the past year, and was planning to increase its trading footprint by another 1.2m sq ft in the next 12 months. The company also invested £85m in improving its fresh food.

Sainsbury's claimed it was now the UK's fastest-growing online food retailer, delivering groceries to 165,000 households a week.

Many retailers have struggled over the past year as consumers grappled with inflation, muted wage growth, government austerity measures and worries about job security. However, on Tuesday official data showed UK inflation edged down in February to its lowest level in over a year, keeping hopes alive that the squeeze on Britons' finances would ease this year.

webTitle: FTSE edges higher and pound holds steady during budget speech

fields.standfirst: Estate agency Savills is big loser after changes to stamp duty on £2m homes
fields.body:
Leading shares and the pound were little changed during George Osborne's budget speech, although the FTSE 100 did move from negative to positive territory.

As the chancellor stood up at 12.31, the FTSE 100 was down 5 points at 5886, while sterling was worth $1.5835 and €1.1971. By the time he had finished at 1.29pm, the pound was back where it began, while the FTSE 100 was up about 8 points at 5899.

Traders said many of the measures had been widely trailed, while investors are likely to wait for any reaction from the ratings agencies to news of an £11bn reduction in the deficit by 2017. James Knightley at ING Bank said:

The government debt/GDP ratio should be falling in 2015/16, which may give the ratings agencies some comfort despite recent moves to put the UK's AAA rating on negative watch.

Retailers were lifted by the news of a relaxation in Sunday trading laws during the Olympics, with J Sainsbury up 10p at 315.5p (also helped by good figures from the supermarket group).

North Sea oil companies benefited from news of further investment, with Centrica climbing 3.2p to 315.8p, EnQuest moving 2.2p higher at 130.6p and Faroe Petroleum adding 11.5p to 163p.

Housebuilders moved ahead on the prospect of a brighter economic outlook, with Bovis Homes 20.1p better at 513p.

But Savills, the upmarket estate agency, was down 15.4p at 366.8p on a new 7% stamp duty tax for homes worth more than £2m.

And banks moved lower as the chancellor adjusted the bank levy so they would not benefit from his corporation tax cuts. Barclays is down 2.55p at 242.95p while Lloyds Banking Group is 0.385p lower at 35.805p.

Finally, Domino's Pizza rose 2.5p to 457.9 as the chancellor added VAT to hot food takeaways from supermarkets, making a more level playing field.

webTitle: Power supply company APR Energy blows a fuse after results delay

fields.standfirst: Company says 2011 results are in line with forecasts but delays in putting out full figures hit shares
fields.body:
Temporary power supplier APR Energy has blown a fuse as investors had their first chance to react to an after hours update from the company on Tuesday.

APR, which last year reversed into the Horizon company owned by Pizza Express and Punch Taverns tycoon Hugh Osmond, had been due to issue results on Thursday. But it said late on Tuesday that it would not now be putting the figures out until 16 April

due to the complexities in reporting and accounting for the various corporate transactions which have taken place during the period.

It said the financial results for 2011 were in line with current forecasts, with revenues up 65% and earnings up 63%, and it continued to see strong demand across all regions. But its shares are down 250p to 850p - a 23% decline. Analyst John Lawson at Investec said:

APR Energy has taken the market by surprise by publishing pro-forma twelve month 2011 figures two days ahead of schedule. These look fine (in line with estimates), but the group will not be publishing full audited figures until April. This is unfortunate and will not be well received by investors, whatever the reasoning, as it leaves more questions unanswered. There is still be a good underlying story to tell, we believe, but this hiatus will not help the near-term investment case - even more proof of the pudding will be needed to galvanise some investors now.

Peel Hunt moved from hold to sell, and analyst Andrew Nussey said:

We remain supporters of the APR model, the attractive levels of returns and the long-term potential of the independent power producer market. However, we believe that until the order intake accelerates, visibility on 2013 increases and the uncertainties associated with the delay in results are removed, the shares are likely to come under pressure. We therefore downgrade our target price to 975p, and move our recommendation to sell.

webTitle: Cable & Wireless Communications dips on talk of Panama share sale

fields.standfirst: Reports suggest Panamanian government could dispose of part of its 49% stake in CWC subsidiary
fields.body:
Cable & Wireless Communications has slipped back on talk the Panamanian government may be considering selling part of its stake in the company's operations in the country.

The government owns 49% of CWC Panama, and local reports suggests it may dispose of around 5%, which would be worth around $70m. The funds would be used to finance infrastructure projects in the country, including improvements to its drinking water systems.

CWC would be likely to get first refusal on any shares sold, and analysts at Espirito Santo said:

As CWC has management control of the asset we believe it would try to acquire this stake, at the right price. CWC is likely to look at a deal like this on a cash-relative basis, considering reduced cash leakage as well as upfront cost, but it shouldn't have any implications for potential dividend payments going forward. We note across CWC's portfolio of assets there are a number of other government stakes which could be sold down to raise funds in the same way.

The company's recent trading update showed a weaker than expected performance in Panama, mainly due to increased competition in mobile following the introduction of number portability. CWC has been investing more in gaining new subscribers and retaining existing ones, as well as launching new products such as the iPhone. Espirito Santo said:

We believe this strategy will squeeze the other operators in the market such that one of them may be forced to exit because of mounting cash flow losses which would be positive for CWC (four mobile players is not sustainable in the longer term). CWC Panama should still be viewed as a good business which is generating strong cash returns, in our view.

CWC shares are currently down 0.24p at 32.09p. Meanwhile its one time partner Cable & Wireless Worldwide has fallen 1.05p to 36.95p after the idea of an imminent cash offer from potential predator Tata Communications was played down.

webTitle: Ocado drops 4% after Panmure sell note as online grocer offers lapsed customers free delivery

fields.standfirst: Panmure analyst believes Ocado's share revival has gone too far amid optimistic sales forecasts
fields.body:
Ocado, the online grocer, is among the biggest fallers in the mid-cap index after a sell note from Panmure Gordon.

The company's shares have been climbing his year as problems at its distribution centre eased, and it issued an upbeat trading statement earlier this month. But Panmure's Philip Dorgan - a noted bear on the business - says in a new note the price has moved too far:

The shares have moved sharply higher in 2012, boosted by Ocado's statement that it has 'largely' overcome the operational challenges that it faced last year. The short position has eased slightly and a number of existing shareholders have topped up. We think that it has gone too far.
Its multichannel competitors are growing faster, helped by both the structural advantage that is Click & Collect and their greater scale. We think that Ocado will continue to struggle to demonstrate operational leverage, so we remain sellers, with a target price of 50p. Ocado is currently searching for a new finance director after the departure of Andrew Bracey. We think that – despite the fact that consensus continues to drift lower – a new finance director will be keen to rebase forecasts. For a start, the expectation that it expects to see sales growth accelerate through 2012 looks a tad optimistic. Yesterday, Ocado emailed lapsed customers with an offer of an Ocado Delivery Pass free for six months. We don't think that this will be helpful to profitability.

The company's shares are currently 4.9p lower at 118.4p.

fields.bodyText: Game Group may be in serious trouble but the rest of retail sector is helping to give the market a lift. J Sainsbury is up 7.4p at 312.9p after it beat analysts expectations for the fourth quarter, while Marks & Spencer was lifted 6p to 386p following a positive update from Spanish group Inditex, owner of the Zara chain. Debenhams is up 3.25p at 79.8p as Societe Generale raised its target price from 69p to 78p in the wake of Tuesday's trading update. Top of the pile however at the moment is building materials group Wolseley, up 70p at £25.63. The company has been lifted by news that Credit Suisse has lifted its price target from £24 to £28.50 with an outperform rating. The bank said: We have increased our earnings per share forecasts by 12% and 22% for 2012/13 and 2013/14 respectively. The majority of the group upgrade is related to an increase in our forecasts for the US. In addition to the improved data on US housing starts and the ABI Index, we cite the Credit Suisse US Homebuilding Team's Monthly Survey of Real Estate Agents as an extremely supportive lead indicator of an improved housing market. The balance of the revision to earnings forecasts relates to our European forecasts where the more resilient start to the year from peers (versus our expectations) has meant we upgrade sales assumptions for 2012 and 2013. The group will report its second quarter result on 27 March. We expect the group to report earnings of £119m, on sales of £2.9bn, implying a margin of 4.1%. We await an update on the asbestos issue that the group highlighted at the first quarter. It commented at the time that the board viewed its exposure to this situation as non-material. Overall, ahead of UK public finances due shortly and of course the budget at lunchtime, the FTSE 100 has edged up 11.55 points to 5902.96. Miners are still in the doldrums following Tuesday's comments from BHP Billiton, down 9.5p at 1955.5p, hinting at a slowdown in demand from China for iron ore. Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation is down 8.5p at 655p after a 7% rise in full year earnings to $3.41bn slightly missed forecasts. The company has come under pressure over its corporate governance and new chairman Mehmet Dalman promised to "progressively refresh" the board. Insurer Aviva is leading the fallers, down 13.6p at 360.1p as its shares went ex-dividend.
fields.headline: Sainsbury and Marks & Spencer help lift retailers, while Wolseley benefits from upgrade
fields.trailText: Supermarket group reports better than expected figures, while Credit Suisse boosts Wolseley
